key_points: Tiger Woods discusses potential return to competitive golf, inspired by Ben Hogan's post-accident career.
Woods contemplates a limited schedule, similar to Hogan's, focusing on just a few events a year.
Both Woods and Hogan experienced career-altering car accidents in February of different years.
Ben Hogan returned to competitive golf in 1950, winning three times, including the U.S. Open, out of nine tournaments.
Hogan, post-accident, never played more than nine tournaments in a single year again.
Hogan's severely damaged legs limited his play to just a few tournaments each year.
Woods has not played any tournaments since the 2020 Masters in November, largely due to back surgeries.
Woods hints at never returning as a top-level player, acknowledging his physical limitations.
A possible schedule for Woods could include major championships and a few other select events, totaling around nine tournaments.
Woods is considering competitive play despite acknowledging his career may not see him return to his peak form.
